messages.content:
I'm going to run a validator on sn1 and it's going to perform very well due to the amount of compute behind it, but initially it's going to have low stake and in Yuma 2 a good validator with small stake on a subnet with a lot of uids is getting hurt in number of ways (due to uint16 precision errors and whatnot).

Please enable Yuma 3, so that dividends are distributed fairly.

Sorry, we do not have any data suggesting Yuma3 is accurate or stable enough to implement at this time. I will talk to the team, but at present this is not a priority for our dev roadmap due to a major release coming soon.

This message suggests to me you don't want honest validators to enter the fray, starting with a supposed knowledge gap as the reason for not implementing  to continue ending the conversation by mentioning it is not on the dev road map and will not be prioritized either. This leads me to rethink my position on sn1.
No, it means there is no evidence that YC3 works.
Or is an optimal solution.
We are working aggressively to improve the subnet. Right now, validation is an endemic problem in Bittensor. I haven't seen conclusive data that YC3 will fix this issue.
You can see from the refactors on iota and beyond that we try to push YC to it's limits, and benefit validators.

We are launching a major refactor - part of that refactor will include pushing for strong Vtrust for honest performers, but to be frank, I have yet to be convinced YC3 is a core part of that solution.
There are a lot of charts, theories, pieces of information, but few concrete implementation examples of subnets.
To be frank, validation as a concept on Bittensor is broken - it's primarily a method to reward investors and stakers.
You can see from my comments in RAO I think it's broken, and we need to rethink tokenomics for owners and discrete subnets more broadly.

It is in effect in sn2 and discussed at length at the church of rao meetings. Only thing I want is for you to be open to all possibilities to achieve more honest validation. As it is in the interest of all in the subnet.
What works for SN2 doesn't work for all subnets, and "discussed at length" is not concrete implementation, but I will have a look at 2 and see if there's any relevance for our IM.

I will just be candid that "turn on YC3" is not something we're going to do without thought - we played with liquid alpha and hyperparameters previously at Rhef's suggestion, and it blew up our subnet, so I am a sceptic - sorry.
Fair enough
Yuma 2 is proven to be unfair and Yuma 3 isn't. It doesn't solve the weight copying problem in itself, just treats the small stake validators fairly.

Liquid Alpha 1 didn't work, that's why it was rewritten, but I'm not asking you to enable it or to change any other parameter, just to switch from a mode which treats small validators unfairly, to the mode that doesn't
the only way to effectively use Yuma 2 is for a subnet owner (who also controls a large validator) to deprive small validators from the dividends they deserve to receive
I'm sure that's not what you are trying to do though - the information about Yuma 3 wasn't published as well as it should have been
there's a team writing a research paper on it with all the math and such but they got reassigned to quality assurance of Uniswap v3 and thus the Yuma 3 whitepaper was put on hold

Yuma 2 author reviewed Yuma 3 and simulations of both and agreed that it's a better implementation of what he was trying to do. Yuma 3 was tested way, way more than Yuma 2 was, so if you are afraid of one of them, then it should be 2, which is clearly unfair and less tested.
Yuma2 is literally tested on 128 subnets. Without a whitepaper to review the math, it is a no go.
I'm not defending YC2, but I am not implementing an untested solution with no math for my team to review.
then we'll run our experimental validator on a high stake

you can review the code, the changes are minimal, there's also a simulator showing the same changes in python and there's a simulator which can show you how the bonds and dividends will look like if you switch to Y3 based on the weights taken from archive subtensor
if you want a quick transition, set bonds moving average to 100000 for a couple of tempos before and after the switch
with sn1 having 1024 uids the rounding errors will be more expressed here than anywhere else
dude, not without a whitepaper. Ask me again when that is done.

I am not reviewing code and running a simulator of a solution that is again, untested. If we have dev time, we will look at this, but to repeat, we are not moving our delivery roadmap for a feature that does not have a whitepaper, and is not provable outside of anecdotal evidence. Sorry.
I am supportive of improving validators - my read of CoR is the jury is out on YC3 and there are a lot of dissenting voices.
I appreciate your passion for this, but we will focus on our development roadmap over this until such a state that it is proved stable and usable.

there's only voice that was dissenting but it was dissenting against setting `bond_penalty` to a value of `<1`, not Yuma 3 itself and when it was made clear that `bond_penalty` (which I'm not asking you to change) does not need to be changed, he laid down his weapon and never protested it again.
whitepaper.
not unreasonable to ask for some documentation.
@0xcacti whitepaper when?
let me know when it's done, and we will consider.
w.r.t YC2 was it Isabella who reviewed it, or Eugene?

I wasn't here when YC2 was implemented, but YC3 was reviewed by a lot of people. It's not long, mostly stops upscaling bonds, so that for example if a validator that holds > _kappa_ stake gives a micro weight to a miner, they don't get a full bond tank that takes a whole day to get back to a normal level
... in the best case - because YC2 bonds don't ever decay so once acquired the bond state can persist for weeks or months (as it was the case in sn9)

in fact Yuma 2 paper didn't assume the bonds won't decay or that they will be upscaled - these are bugs in the implementation with consequences so massive that the set of fixes incremented a major version number
you can even say that Yuma 3 is a better implementation of the Yuma 2 paper than Yuma 2 is
You literally said YC3 was reviewed by the YC2 author - which author?
Whitepaper with discussion of all the yumas and potential future yumas coming moderately soon.
as if 3 Yumas are not enough 🫠

But we’re going live with a new incentive mechanism that will focus subnet 1 on the most exciting and competitive part of our current codebase which is test time compute 🙏
The target launch date is Wednesday next week
If you’ve mined here before the main thing to know is that you’ll need to optimize for the multi step reasoning / GAN task as this will be the main game in town

You can do this in many ways, it doesn’t need SOTA hardware or models, just a really tight workflow that enables your LLM to create solid research reports very quickly. You can try fine tuning and quantizing some 7Bs or MoEs, use ensemble approaches or something even smarter

This next epoch of subnet 1 is about incentivizing two things; the creation of powerful agentic responses and discerning between reference answers and miner responses. The purpose of this is to create the fastest deep researcher in the world. Anyone will be able to use our apex api and platform to use these fast research responses and we will also be focused on publishing research papers that share this work with the AI community

This release will be really impressive.

we are starting with miner documentation, code for validators, a base miner framework (that will need significant improvement) and some introductory comms about the reasons for this change.

**Assumptions**
1. **Majority control** – A single actor controls most of the miner nodes in the subnet (e.g., \~70%), including both generators and discriminators.
2. **Source recognition** – This actor can reliably recognize when the generation being evaluated comes from their own generator (via caching query-response hash).


**Attack process**
* **When their own generation is being evaluated:**
  Produce outputs that look correct to the validator’s scoring logic but are easy for honest discriminators to misjudge. This lowers the honest side’s accuracy, which directly increases the generator’s score.
  The attacker’s own discriminators can vote either way here — total coalition gain is unaffected — but voting “wrong” shifts more reward from discriminators to the generator if desired.
* **When another miner’s generation is being evaluated:**
  Attacker’s discriminators always vote correctly according to the validator’s standard. This maximizes their discriminator rewards and simultaneously reduces the other generator’s score to near zero.
* **To amplify impact:**
  Operate more miner nodes to increase the probability that an attacker-controlled generator is selected for evaluation, and keep the recognition mechanism robust so attacker discriminators never fail to identify their own outputs.
We have some notebooks on majority ownership and the advantage being minimal, but on this exact post
We want generators to make generations that look like the validators, this is the point of the network

It's also the design that you should always, if you know that it's not the validator, say so so that generator gets penalized. This is the main gameplay loop. At most this benefits your ability to say that it is a validator, but the reverse is not true, this doesn't give you more information on whether its another miner or not. Stay posted for a notebook

## Release Announcement v3.0.0

Hey SN1, we are live!

### Miners
Make sure to update your code with the new requirements, see as an example:
https://github.com/macrocosm-os/apex/blob/main/miner.py

### Validators
1. Copy config/mainnet.yaml.example to config/mainnet.yaml: `cp config/mainnet.yaml.example config/mainnet.yaml`
2. Replace `TAVILY_API_KEY` with your actual key in `config/mainnet.yaml`.
3. Replace `CHUTES_API_KEY` with your actual key in `config/mainnet.yaml`.
4. Set your `coldkey` and `hotkey` in `config/mainnet.yaml`.
5. Run:
```
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh # installs uv
uv venv --python=3.11 && uv pip install -e '.[dev]'
. .venv/bin/activate
python validator.py -c config/mainnet.yaml
```
(Auto-updater is coming in the next patch release).

Happy mining!

## Release Announcement v3.0.1

### Changelog
  - Add a weight synchronizer to improve vTrust.
  - Add an auto-updater (python and pm2).
  - Minor bug fixes.

### Validators
```
git switch main
git pull

# Run the auto-updater (recommended):
python3 scripts/autoupdater.py

# Alternatively, if you prefer PM2:
bash scripts/autoupdater_pm2.sh

# If you prefer not to use the auto-updater:
uv venv --python 3.11 && uv pip install '.[dev]' && uv run python validator.py
```

Optionally, you can change the default port for weight sync (default: 8001). Add the following to your `config/mainnet.yaml`:
```
weight_syncer:
  kwargs:
    port: 8001  # Put your port here.
```

Serving the weight-sync API is not required, but it slightly improves vTrust.

### Miners
No action required.


Cheers 🫡

Hi.  This channel is for the Apex Subnet (subnet #1), and is for people who are operating miners and/or validators in the subnet and who need support running their neurons.

With respect to generalized staking on Bittensor, please see this **very important** article in the #❓・faq channel: https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1215386737661055056/1365343696459141171 -- **make sure that you read this article FIRST.**

I'd recommend making sure your applications are up to date.  But if you continue to get slippage errors, it likely means that the liquidity in the underlying swap pool is not balanced or you're experiencing a sandwich attack.  Please be cautious.  For more assistance in how to approach staking to a subnet as an investment/trading/profit opportunity, please make sure you check out the dTAO Discord, and if you are using a specialized front-end (like Taostats), you can also ask Taostats in their Discord for help.  There are invite links to these in the "Useful Links" article in the #❓・faq channel.

Note that in any Discord server: DO NOT respond to any DMs that anyone sends you.  We DO NOT reach out to people via DM (and neither do the mods of the dTAO or Taostats servers), even as a "reply" or to "follow up", and don't assign people to "support" to do this.  Anyone DMing or calling you right now is a scammer, even if they look like me, another mod, admin, WalletConnect Foundation team member, etc (they are imposters).  And if anyone invites you to DM them for "a guide" or "resources" because they "can't post links", it's a scam.  Lastly, do not click on links to "support servers" to "open/raise a ticket" -- **this is also a scam**

A lot of the answers to your questions are going to be in the #❓・faq channel.  For example, here's the article on how to get testnet tokens: https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1215386737661055056/1220066293114470410
should not just cut it all of a sudden, that totally breaks the rules of SN1
1024 UIDs is a really special historic record
Totally agree. Why wasn't there any discussion? How does this help the SN?

While in the short term the adjustment may be abrupt, it does help in the long term for the subnet. The amount of hotkeys means that your earnings per uid were 4 times lower than on other subnets. Less uids means more frequent evaluation, higher earnings per key, and higher score stability.

I find this decision quite concerning. It feels more like a one-sided change, and something that could affect whether people register really should not happen without some prior discussion. Also, since people can always register multiple UIDs and try different strategies, it is hard to see how this adjustment truly brings the intended benefits.

The decision has already been made, and it wasn't made by us. You had as much notice as I, but overall I think this is a positive change. There's going to be 4x less redundant verification. That's an immense win for mining and validating costs. Additionally, it means you can compete as a generator and a discriminator 4 times as often. Aside from the sharp adjustment, I am only seeing upsides.
Based on the continued registrations, even in light of this announcement, I'm assuming that miners are willing to bear the risk of deregistration in return for emissions until it happens.

Who actually made that decision? Was there any opposition voiced at all? If the SN owner really wanted a similar effect, simply increasing the sampling size would have done it without such a drastic change. Why reshape the whole subnet? Does this mean all the miners who registered before are basically treated like fools?
Not sure who made it. But look, we now know that uids will be trimmed. But still the registration slots are all taken. Therefore, some people do not mind being deregged.
Sampling size is not similar to reducing uids, reducing uids reduces the population, so the peer to peer interactions do not change like with changing sampling size
Those could very well just be bots, and they might not even be aware of this change at all.

That's possible, but at this point neither you and I are able to stop it. Bittensor is constantly changing, so let's look at the positives of the change. Uid assignment is random, so no one is more or less likely to be in the trimmed uids. Additionally, this means that each hotkey will see a 4x increase in emissions. This simplifies infra, registration, and evaluation.
So we would not take this step on our own, unless Bittensor enforces it automatically, right?
I don't see a lot of value in 1024 UIDs
it's been a Novelty of SN1
but to be frank it is more of an encumbrance / cost
we had a use case for loads of UIDs on iota, but we don't need them yet
most SN designs really don't need 1024 UIDs at this stage of Bittensor
Once the number goes down, it cannot go back up. This really is not the right time to rush into such a change.
Initially it will be set to 256, then it will be allowed to be smaller, then the plan is allow it to scale back up again
In the short term this is permanent but in the long run this will be a dynamic parameter
So we would not take this step on our own, right?
Why does it matter? The decision is made.
There are subnets where 20 UIDs is the best idea
At different times, SN1 has needed more or less
1024 makes development harderr
I think we would take this decision - we'd consult with the community, but I don't see any real benefit to 1024 slots.
If it was a two door system, this would be better
You could flex / up down as needed
Until the timeline for that is clear, I'm more inclined to preserve the optionality, but 1024 doesn't have any benefit right now
I think this is not necessarily something forced, but rather something left up to the subnet owner to decide.
It is, just SN1 has a legacy footprint
we ain't going to 3 UIDs just yet

Okay.  So if you're seeing metagraph info, such as "ACTIVE", that's a flag that's only TRUE if you are running a validator.  It means that you have set weights within the subnet's `activity_cutoff` (the number of blocks that a validator has to set weights, or it'll be set to FALSE).

If you are running a miner node, and if you see ACTIVE set to FALSE, it's okay.  You're not setting weights, you're not a validator, it doesn't matter. : )
